Lambert Ace Of Blue Hens;
Capt. Neu And Clark
Lead Jay Speedsters
By JULIAN ADLER
In augurating their season against
one of the strongest opponents scheduled, the Johns Hopkins runners will
meet Delaware University at Homewood tomorrow afternoon. The field

because of the fact that this is the

slightly stronger aggregation.
Lambert Outstanding
One of the outstanding members
of the opposition is Lambert, a sprinter and broad-jumper, who has proven
himself a consistent winner against
the Black and Blue. Ted Graziano and
Willard Neu are the Hopkins men
who will attempt to match the Delaware ace's speed, and a close duel is
anticipated when these runners meet.
George Carey is another competitor who is expected to prove a worthy
foe to the Hopkins' weight men since
he secured first in three events against
the Jays last year. Carey, who also
starred on the Delaware swimming
squad that recently defeated the
Jays, will attempt to duplicate his
tank victories on the track. The men
competing in the weights for Hopkins
are Marovek, Chancellor, Ellis, Craziano, and Carlin. The first two are
veterans who have been coming close
to Carey for the last two years, and
who hope to finally turn the tables on
their opponent tomorrow.
Delaware Strong
In 1934 the Delaware team was
strongest in the field events, holding
the Black and Blue to 7 points. Hopkins, however, is now definitely
stronger in this department than they
were, and expects to make a more
creditable showing. Outstanding for
the Jays are Neu in the broad jump,
and B ac and Jarmon in the high jump.
Hopkins undoubtedly will be favored in the distances. Last year the
Blue Jays scored 26 out of 27 markers in these races, and most of the
men who accounted for this total will
await the starters' gun again tomorrow. Some of the men who scored
heavily in 1934 are Paul Holtzman,
Leonard Emmert, Earl Sholtes, and
Roland Clark. The former two will
run the mile and two-mile respectively; Sholtes will compete in the mile
and half-mile, whie Clark is entered
in the latter event. In addition to
these men, others who will add to the
Jays' strength are Brown, Lyman,
Hughes Castelle, Maisel, Johnson, and
Miller

Sudent umpires for football games
were announced Wednesday afternoon
by Reuben Baer, who is in charge of
the softball tournament.
Those who were selected to umpire
the games are: Bernie Cherry, Al
Savage, Dick Byer, Ray Fertig, Arnold Glantz, Ernie Pieper, Abe Edelman, Hal Zheutlin, Dan Goldman, and
Dick Pasternak. At the head of all
these umpires is Ronald Levy, a former Hopkins student and now a graduate student. He will be the highest
official in all cases.
The schedule of umpires for each
day follows:
Tuesday-Frat Games: Levy, Cherry. Class Games: Goldman, Paterflak.
Wednesday -Frat Games Levy,
Byer. Class Games: Fertig, Cherry,
Savage.
Thursday-Frat Games: Levy, Savage. Class Games: Zheutlin, Fertig.

The latter
proved that he had great natural
speed on the gridiron last fall, and is
attempting to apply it to track. This
necessitates an adaption of stride
which is difficult to achieve, but
Coach Hambleton has been working
with Kelly, and believes that he has
good potentialities.

I was working way late at the
office one nightand ran out ofcigarettes,
When Jim the watchman came through
I tackled him for a smoke.
"Sure," says Jim, and he handed
overapack ofChesterfields."Go ahead,
Mr. Kent, take three or four."
Jim said he'd smoked a lot ofcigarettes in his time, but he'd put Chesterfield up in front of any of'em when
it came to taste.
... "and they ain't a bit strong
either," is the way Jim put it.
That was the first Chesterfield I
ever smoked. And I'm right there with
him, too, when he says it's a ding
good cigarette.

Mile Relay Probable
While the regular meet will end at
3.00 p m., Hambleton intends to suggest a mile relay to be run between
the halves of the lacrosse game. Although this event won't ennnt on the
score, it should provide excellent
training for the Penn relays, in which
Hopkins plans to compete.

Lambert Ace Of Blue Hens;
Capt. Neu And Clark
Lead Jay Speedsters
By JULIAN ADLER
In augurating their season against
one of the strongest opponents scheduled, the Johns Hopkins runners will
meet Delaware University at Homewood tomorrow afternoon. The field

because of the fact that this is the
rubber encounter, both teams having
captured two of the last four contests. As every meet has been won

slightly stronger aggregation.
Lambert Outstanding
One of the outstanding members
of the opposition is Lambert, a sprinter and broad-jumper, who has proven
himself a consistent winner against
the Black and Blue. Ted Graziano and
Willard Neu are the Hopkins men
who will attempt to match the Delaware ace's speed, and a close duel is
anticipated when these runners meet.
George Carey is another competitor who is expected to prove a worthy
foe to the Hopkins' weight men since
he secured first in three events against
the Jays last year. Carey, who also
starred on the Delaware swimming
squad that recently defeated the
Jays, will attempt to duplicate his
tank victories on the track. The men
competing in the weights for Hopkins
are Marovek, Chancellor, Ellis, Craziano, and Carlin. The first two are
veterans who have been coming close
to Carey for the last two years, and
who hope to finally turn the tables on
their opponent tomorrow.
Delaware Strong
In 1934 the Delaware team was
strongest in the field events, holding
the Black and Blue to 7 points. Hopkins, however, is now definitely
stronger in this department than they
were, and expects to make a more
creditable showing. Outstanding for
the Jays are Neu in the broad jump,
and B ac and Jarmon in the high jump.
Hopkins undoubtedly will be favored in the distances. Last year the
Blue Jays scored 26 out of 27 markers in these races, and most of the
men who accounted for this total will
await the starters' gun again tomorrow. Some of the men who scored
heavily in 1934 are Paul Holtzman,
Leonard Emmert, Earl Sholtes, and
Roland Clark. The former two will
run the mile and two-mile respectively; Sholtes will compete in the mile
and half-mile, whie Clark is entered
in the latter event. In addition to
these men, others who will add to the
Jays' strength are Brown, Lyman,
Hughes Castelle, Maisel, Johnson, and
Miller

by Reuben Baer, who is in charge of
the softball tournament.
Those who were selected to umpire
the games are: Bernie Cherry, Al
Savage, Dick Byer, Ray Fertig, Arnold Glantz, Ernie Pieper, Abe Edelman, Hal Zheutlin, Dan Goldman, and
Dick Pasternak. At the head of all
these umpires is Ronald Levy, a former Hopkins student and now a graduate student. He will be the highest
official in all cases.
The schedule of umpires for each
day follows:
Tuesday-Frat Games: Levy, Cherry. Class Games: Goldman, Paterflak.
Wednesday -Frat Games Levy,
Byer. Class Games: Fertig, Cherry,
Savage.
Thursday-Frat Games: Levy, Savage. Class Games: Zheutlin, Fertig.

Newcomers In Line-Up
In the high hurdles Buc and Jarman stand out for the Black and
Blue, while Lelmeis, Dertzbaugh and
Wingert will face the opposition in
the low-hurdle event.
Aside from last year's veterans,
Hopkins possesses several newcomers in the sprints who promise to
balance the Jay line-up. Lankford has
shown great ability in the 440, while
Litwin, Willen, Lyle and Charley Kelly have been teaming up the cinders
In the shorter dashes.
The latter
proved that he had great natural
speed on the gridiron last fall, and is
attempting to apply it to track. This
necessitates an adaption of stride
which is difficult to achieve, but
Coach Hambleton has been working
with Kelly, and believes that he has
good potentialities.

Mile Relay Probable
While the regular meet will end at
3.00 p m., Hambleton intends to suggest a mile relay to be run between
the halves of the lacrosse game. Although this event won't ennnt on the
score, it should provide excellent
training for the Penn relays, in which
Hopkins plans to compete.
